title: Maxitive functions with respect to general orders

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In decision-making, maxitive functions are used for worst-case and bestcase evaluations. Maxitivity gives rise to a rich structure that is well-studied in the context of the pointwise order. In this article, we investigate maxitivity with respect to general preorders and provide a representation theorem for such functions. The results are illustrated for different stochastic orders in the literature, including the usual stochastic order, the increasing convex/concave order, and the dispersive order. Key words: Maxitive functions, representation theorem, stochastic orderings


AMS 2020 Subject Classification: 62C86, 47H05, 28A25, 91B05

## 1. InTRODUCTION

In decision-making under risk and uncertainty, one typically considers a set of gambles $X$ and a function $\psi: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, which assigns to each gamble $f \in X$ a value $\psi(f)$, representing its price, risk, or utility. In the context of imprecise probabilities, such functions are referred to as lower/upper previsions; see [31]. In financial mathematics, they are commonly called risk measures [12] or nonlinear expectations [23].

In many cases, the function $\psi$ takes the form of an expectation, where the value $\psi(f)$ represents the weighted average of the values associated with the gamble $f$. However, decisions are often based on assessments of best-case or worst-case scenarios, rather than relying on averages. These evaluations are captured by maxitive functions. A function $\psi$ is called maxitive if it satisfies the condition $\psi(f \vee g)=\max \{\psi(f), \psi(g)\}$ for any two gambles $f$ and $g$, where $f \vee g$ denotes the pointwise supremum of $f$ and $g$.

Maxitive functions play a crucial role in possibility theory $[10,11,34]$ and serve as aggregation functions in various fields such as economics, information fusion, and control theory [13, 29]. Under reasonable assumptions, these functions can be represented in terms of maxitive integrals, such as the Shilkret integral discussed in [3, 16, 24, 28]. Beyond decision theory, maxitive functions also arise in other areas, including idempotent or tropical analysis [17] and large deviations theory [15, 16, 25].

In probability theory, statistics, and particularly decision theory, a wide range of criteria exist to define order relations between gambles beyond the pointwise order [22, 27]. While most of the literature has focused on maxitivity with respect to pointwise order, less attention has been paid to maxitivity with respect to more general orders. The aim of this work is to fill this gap by studying maxitivity in the context of preorders, which enables the extension of the maxitive structure and its beneficial properties to a wider class of functions. The main result of this paper provides a characterization and representation of countably maxitive functions on a preordered space. The proof relies on recent representation results from $[7,18]$ for convex monotone functions on spaces of bounded continuous functions, and incorporates dual representations of sublevel sets as discussed in [9]. A key assumption is that the preorder $\preccurlyeq$ admits a numerical representation given by $f \preccurlyeq g$ if and only if $\phi(f) \leq \phi(g)$ for all $\phi$ in some Polish space ${ }^{1} \Phi$, where the mapping $\phi \mapsto \phi(f)$ is lower semicontinuous ${ }^{2}$ for all $f \in X$. The paper is structured as follows: In Section 2, we provide some motivation for maxitivity in decision-making and possibility theory. Section 3 introduces the basic concepts and definitions. In Section 4, we present and prove the main result. Section 5 explores variations of the main result in the context of different stochastic orders. Finally, the appendix provides representation results for maxitive risk measures on $C_{b}$, along with auxiliary results related to quantile functions.

# 2. MAXITIVE FUNCTIONS IN DECISION-MAKING 

Let $X$ be a set of gambles of the form $f: S \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$, where each gamble $f$ assigns a loss $f(s)$ to each possible state $s \in S .{ }^{3}$ We consider a decision maker who evaluates the gambles using a decision function $\psi: X \rightarrow(-\infty, \infty]$, which in risk analysis is commonly referred to as a risk measure; see [12]. We adopt the convention that $\psi(f) \leq \psi(g)$ indicates that the gamble $g$ is considered riskier than the gamble $f$. The set of acceptable gambles for the decision maker is defined by the acceptance set, given by $A:=\{f \in X: \psi(f) \leq 0\}$.

We assume that the decision maker believes in an ordering $\preccurlyeq$, thus evaluating gambles $f, g \in X$ satisfying $f \preccurlyeq g$ with $\psi(f) \leq \psi(g)$. This could be the pointwise order, in which case $f \preccurlyeq_{\mathrm{pw}} g$ if and only if $f(s) \leq g(s)$ for all $s \in S$. In decision-making, however, there are numerous methods for comparing gambles beyond pointwise ordering. These include comparisons based on quantiles, the spread of quantiles, and other distributional properties. Such considerations lead to various stochastic orders, including the usual stochastic order, the increasing convex stochastic order, or the dispersive order. In the first case, we assign probabilities to the states in $S$ and order gambles $f, g \in X$ using their quantile functions, i.e., $f \preccurlyeq_{\mathrm{st}} g$ if and only if $q_{f}(u) \leq q_{g}(u)$ for all $u \in(0,1)$ (or equivalently, if the cumulative distribution function of $f$ is pointwise greater than the cumulative distribution function of $g$ ). For further examples of stochastic orders and their definitions, we refer to the monographs [22, 27].

In this article, we focus on decision functions whose acceptance sets remain invariant under worst-case aggregation. To be more precise, consider a decision maker with an

We also want to mention that in the literature, there are different versions of maxitivity, all of which require $\psi\left(\vee_{i \in I} f_{i}\right)=\sup _{i \in I} \psi\left(f_{i}\right)$, but for different families $\left(f_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$, for which the supremum $\vee_{i \in I} f_{i}$ is assumed to exist; see e.g. [3, 28]. For example, $\psi$ is called completely maxitive if this holds for all families $\left(f_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$, and $\psi$ is called countably maxitive if this holds for countable families $\left(f_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$. Furthermore, a topological perspective on maxitivity, which is closely linked to the large deviation principle, was recently investigated in [16]; see also $[15,25]$.
2.1. Maxitivity for the pointwise order in the context of possibility theory; see $[10,11,34]$. As a simple example, consider a loss $f$ that depends on three possible scenarios $S=\{$ good, average, bad $\}$, each with a certain plausibility given by $\pi: S \rightarrow$ $[0,1]$. The weighted worst-case criterion then leads to the completely maxitive function

$$
\psi(f)=\max _{s \in S} f(s) \pi(s)
$$

on the space of positive gambles $f: S \rightarrow[0, \infty]$. We note that this example generalizes to arbitrary state spaces $S$. Moreover, the mapping $\sup _{s \in S} f(s) \pi(s)$ coincides with the Shilkret integral $\int^{S} f \mathrm{~d} \Pi$ with respect to the possibility measure $\Pi$, which assigns each subset $B \subset S$ the value $\Pi(B):=\sup _{s \in B} \pi(s)$, where $\pi$ is a possibility distribution; see e.g. $[3,5,19,28]$. Another closely related example is the penalized worst-case evaluation $\sup _{s \in S}\{f(s)-\alpha(s)\}$ for some penalty $\alpha: S \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$. Again this is a completely maxitive function on the space $X$ of all gambles $f: S \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$. Conversely, it is known that every completely maxitive function $\psi: X \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$, which has the translation property and satisfies $\psi(0) \in \mathbb{R}$, admits the representation

$$
\psi(f)=\sup _{s \in S}\{f(s)-\alpha(s)\} \quad \text { for all } f \in X
$$

for some penalty $\alpha: S \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$; see [3, Corollary 7]. The right-hand side in the previous equation corresponds to the so-called convex integral, which is obtained as a transformation of the Shilkret integral; see [3]. In the translation-invariant case (particularly for monetary risk measures), these considerations show that maxitive functions with respect to the pointwise order take the form (2.1) of a penalized worstcase evaluation over the state space.
2.2. Maxitivity with respect to other orders. As an illustration, we start with the usual stochastic order. In this case, we order the distributions of the gambles according to their quantile functions. We recall that for two gambles $f$ and $g$, there exists a gamble $f \vee_{\text {st }} g$ whose quantile function is the smallest one that dominates the quantiles $q_{f}$ and $q_{g}$; see [22]. A decision function is then maxitive if $\psi\left(f \vee_{\text {st }} g\right)=\max \{\psi(f), \psi(g)\}$

However, in this context, the relevant 'states' refer to the levels of the quantile functions. More formally, suppose we have two gambles $f$ and $g$, where $f$ is acceptable but $f \vee_{\text {st }} g$ is not acceptable, for a decision function $\psi$ with acceptance set $A$. 0<\psi\left(f \vee_{\mathrm{st}} g\right) \leq \psi\left(f \vee_{\mathrm{st}} h\right)=\max \{\psi(f), \psi(h)\}
$$

Given that $\psi(f) \leq 0$, this implies $\psi(h)>0$, meaning that $h$ is not acceptable. In other words, maxitivity with respect to the usual stochastic order implies that risky quantiles at certain levels ('bad states') cannot be compensated by less risky quantiles at other levels ('good states'). When dealing with probability distributions, it seems natural to consider quantities (that are closely linked to the distribution) as the relevant 'states'. A typical example of such a maxitive function is the Value at Risk, which is widely used in the financial industry. Formally, the Value at Risk at level $s \in(0,1)$, defined by $\operatorname{VaR}_{s}(f):=q_{f}(s)$, is maxitive with respect to the usual stochastic order but is not maxitive with respect to the pointwise order; see [32].

In the context of model aggregation in risk analysis, an interesting motivation for maxitivity with respect to the usual stochastic order was recently presented in [32], where the topic is discussed in great detail. Simplifying their example, consider a risk analyst who evaluates random losses using different methods, resulting in a set of possible risk models $\left\{f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right\}$, which are aggregated into a worst-case model $f^{*}:=f_{1} \vee_{\text {st }} \cdots \vee_{\text {st }} f_{n}$. Under maxitivity, we obtain the desirable property that the risk of the worst-case model $\psi\left(f^{*}\right)$ equals the worst-case risk $\max \left\{\psi\left(f_{1}\right), \ldots, \psi\left(f_{n}\right)\right\}$. Moreover, it is shown in [32] that every real-valued function $\psi$, which has the translation property, is lower semicontinuous with respect to the convergence in distribution ${ }^{5}$ and is completely maxitive (with respect the usual stochastic order) admits a representation

$$
\psi(f)=\sup _{s \in(0,1)}\left\{q_{f}(s)-\alpha(s)\right\} \quad \text { for all } f
$$

for some penalty $\alpha:(0,1) \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$. The representations in (2.2) and (2.1) are closely related, as (2.2) can be interpreted as an analogue of (2.1), where quantile evaluation replaces scenario-wise evaluation.

Another widely used preorder in decision-making is the dispersive order, which is employed to compare the dispersion or variability of two gambles. Specifically, for two gambles $f, g$, we write $f \preccurlyeq_{\text {disp }} g$ if and only if

$$
q_{f}(v)-q_{f}(u) \leq q_{g}(v)-q_{g}(u) \quad \text { whenever } 0<u<v<1
$$

For any two gambles $f$ and $g$, there exists a gamble $f \vee_{\text {disp }} g$, which is the least upper bound of $f$ and $g$ with respect to $\preccurlyeq_{\text {disp }}$. Intuitively, $f \vee_{\text {disp }} g$ is the least dispersed gamble that is more dispersed than both $f$ and $g$; see [22]. We say that a function $\psi: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is maxitive with respect to $\preccurlyeq_{\text {disp }}$ if $\psi\left(f \vee_{\text {disp }} g\right)=\max \{\psi(f), \psi(g)\}$ for any two gambles $f, g$. In this context, maxitivity once again ensures that losses in certain states cannot be offset by gains in others. Here, the relevant 'states' correspond to all pairs of levels $(u, v)$ with $0<u<v<1$, at which the quantile spread $q_{g}(v)-q_{g}(u)$ is evaluated. Thereby, maxitivity with respect to the dispersive order implies that risky

These ideas naturally extend to other partial orders. Consider a decision-maker who compares gambles based on the evaluations of certain relevant features represented by a set $\Phi$ of functions, i.e., $f \preccurlyeq g$ if and only if $\phi(f) \leq \phi(g)$ for all $\phi \in \Phi .{ }^{6}$ In this situation, assuming that any two gambles have a least upper bound, a decision function $\psi: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is called maxitive if it satisfies $\psi(f \vee \Phi g)=\max \{\psi(f), \psi(g)\}$ for all gambles $f, g$. We prove in this paper that, in the translation-invariant case and under reasonable assumptions, maxitive functions can be represented in the form

$$
\psi(f)=\sup _{\phi \in \Phi}\{\phi(f)-\alpha(\phi)\}
$$

for some penalty function $\alpha: \Phi \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$. However, in general, a function that admits a representation (2.3) is not necessarily maxitive. To ensure this, the penalty has to satisfy an additional stability condition. Furthermore, we want to emphasize that the $\phi$ 's generally do not satisfy the translation property (e.g. for the dispersive order), in which case the representation in (2.3) is more involved.

# 3. BASIC CONCEPTS AND DEFINITIONS 

In this section, we provide the formal definitions of maxitivity with respect to general orders and introduce the relevant related concepts. Let $X$ be a non-empty set ${ }^{7}$, which is endowed with a preorder

$$
x \preccurlyeq y \text { if and only if } \phi(x) \leq \phi(y) \text { for all } \phi \in \Phi
$$

where $\Phi$ is a non-empty set of functions $\phi: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$. Throughout this article, the notation $Y \subset X$ denotes non-strict inclusion, meaning that every element of $Y$ is also an element of $X$, allowing for the possibility that $Y=X$.

For the moment, we assume that $(X, \preccurlyeq)$ is an upper semilattice, i.e., for any two elements $x, y \in X$, the set $\{x, y\}$ has a unique supremum $x \vee y \in X$. In that case, the preoder $\preccurlyeq$ is a partial order. ${ }^{8}$ Our focus is on functions $\psi: X \rightarrow(-\infty, \infty]$ that are maxitive with respect to the order $\preccurlyeq$, i.e.,

$$
\psi(x \vee y)=\max \{\psi(x), \psi(y)\} \quad \text { for all } x, y \in X
$$

Note that the supremum, and thus maxitivity, depends on the order $\preccurlyeq$. Such maxitive functions are characterized as follows:

Lemma 3.1. Let $(X, \preccurlyeq)$ be an upper semilattice. For a function $\psi: X \rightarrow(-\infty, \infty]$, the following conditions are equivalent:
(i) $\psi$ is maxitive.
(ii) $\psi$ is monotone ${ }^{9}$ and has upwards directed sublevel sets ${ }^{10}$.

\phi\left(y_{i}\right) \geq \phi\left(x_{i}\right) \text { for all } \phi \in \Phi_{i} \quad \text { and } \quad \psi\left(y_{i}\right)<\psi\left(x_{1} \vee x_{2}\right)

$$

\phi(y) \geq \phi\left(x_{i}\right) \text { for all } \phi \in \Phi_{i} \quad \text { implies } \quad \psi(y) \geq \psi\left(x_{1} \vee x_{2}\right)

The other inequality $\psi\left(x_{1} \vee x_{2}\right) \geq \max \left\{\psi\left(x_{1}\right), \psi\left(x_{2}\right)\right\}$ follows directly from the monotonicity of $\psi$.

Discussion 3.2. We note that our concept includes the classical notion of maxitivity. To see this, let $X$ be the space of all functions $f: S \rightarrow[-\infty, \infty]$ on some state space $S$, and consider the family $\Phi:=\left\{\phi_{s}: s \in S\right\}$, where $\phi_{s}: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is given by $\phi_{s}(f)=$ $\arctan (f(s)) .{ }^{11}$ In this case, $(f \vee g)(s)=\max \{f(s), g(s)\}$, and the concept of maxitivity corresponds to the usual notion of maxitivity studied in the literature; see e.g. [3, 5, 17, 28]. Moreover, the state space $S$ can be identified with the space $\Phi$, which defines the order $\preccurlyeq$. In line with the motivation presented in the previous section, Lemma 3.1(iii) guarantees that losses in certain states cannot be compensated by gains in others. For a general order, this result remains valid when interpreting the elements of $\Phi$ as the relevant states.

Representation results in terms of a weighted or a penalized worst-case evaluation for maxitive functions generally require stronger forms of maxitivity; see e.g. [3, 5]. For instance, $\psi$ is called completely maxitive if

$$
\psi\left(\vee_{i \in I} x_{i}\right)=\sup _{i \in I} \psi\left(x_{i}\right)
$$

for every family $\left(x_{i}\right)_{i \in I} \subset X$. However, for such a notion to make sense, the supremum $\vee_{i \in I} x_{i}$ must exist for arbitrary families. Under additional regularity assumptions, complete maxitivity is already ensured by (finite) maxitivity $[1,15,16,20]$. For our purposes, and to achieve the most elegant mathematical representation results, we will equip the 'state space' $\Phi$ with a Polish topology and assume that the mapping $\Phi \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $\phi \mapsto \phi(x)$, is lower semicontinuous for all $x \in X$; see Section 4. In this context, we work with the following version of maxitivity:
Definition 3.3. Suppose that $(X, \preccurlyeq)$ is countably complete ${ }^{12}$. Then, a function $\psi: X \rightarrow(-\infty, \infty]$ is bounded countably maxitive if for every countable subset $Y \subset X$, we have

$$
\sup _{y \in Y} \psi(y)= \begin{cases}\psi(\vee Y), & \text { if } Y \text { is bounded from above } \\ \infty, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

As in the finite case described in Lemma 3.1, we obtain the following characterization of bounded countable maxitivity:
Lemma 3.4. Suppose that $(X, \preccurlyeq)$ is countably complete. Then, a function $\psi: X \rightarrow$ $(-\infty, \infty]$ is bounded countably maxitive if and only if it is monotone and has countably upwards directed sublevel sets ${ }^{14}$.

Proof. First, suppose that $\psi$ is bounded countably maxitive. Then, for $x, y \in X$ with $x \preccurlyeq y$, it follows from bounded countably maxitivity with $Y:=\{x, y\}$ that $\psi(x) \leq$ $\psi(x \vee y)=\psi(y)$. Moreover, for any countable subset $Y \subset A_{s}$, it holds $\sup _{y \in Y} \psi(y) \leq s$ and bounded countable maxitivity implies that $Y$ is bounded from above with $\vee Y \in A_{s}$.

Second, if $\psi$ is monotone, then the right hand side of (3.1) is greater than the left hand side. If $\psi$ has countably upwards directed sublevel sets, then either $\sup _{y \in Y} \psi(y)=\infty$ or $\sup _{y \in Y} \psi(y)=s<\infty$ in which case $\vee Y \in A_{s}$ so that $\psi(\vee Y) \leq s$, i.e., the right hand side of (3.1) is smaller than the left hand side.

Our representation results are based on duality arguments. Hereby, maxitivity translates dually into the following stability property.
Definition 3.5. Example 5.15. Consider the function $\beta:[0, \infty) \times(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, defined by $\beta(s, u):=s u$. The function

$$
\psi(\xi):=\sup _{(u, v) \in \Delta} \frac{q_{\xi}(v)-q_{\xi}\left(u^{+}\right)}{v-u} \in[0, \infty]
$$

satisfies the equivalent conditions of Corollary 5.14 and is therefore bounded countably maxitive on $\mathcal{M}_{\infty} / \sim$. The value $\psi(\xi)$ corresponds to the Lipschitz constant of $q_{\xi}$. In particular, if $q_{\xi}$ is differentiable, it holds that

$$
\psi(\xi)=\sup _{s \in(0,1)} q_{\xi}^{\prime}(s)
$$

In reliability analysis, the derivative $q_{\xi}^{\prime}(s)$ is referred to as the quantile density function and measures the rate of change of the quantile function; see [30]. When $\xi$ models the uncertain time to failure of a system, $q_{\xi}(u)$ corresponds to the time at which the survival probability of the system is $1-u$. A high value of $q_{\xi}^{\prime}(u)$ implies that small reductions in survival probability correspond to larger increases in time, indicating a slower rate of reliability decline over time. Consequently, $\psi(\xi)$ acts as a measure of the speed at which the reliability of the system decreases, capturing the steepest rate of decline.

# 6. CONCLUSION 

Maxitive functions are widely used in decision-making under risk and uncertainty, particularly for worst-case or best-case evaluations. In this paper, we extend the concept of maxitive functions to a broad class of preorders, providing a unified framework that goes beyond the classical pointwise order. Specifically, our results address the main stochastic orders in the literature, including the usual stochastic order, the increasing convex order, and the dispersive order.

By transitioning from the pointwise order to weaker stochastic orders, we develop a framework that covers a broader class of maxitive functions. Our main result is a representation theorem for bounded countably maxitive functions. In the translationinvariant case, we obtain representation results in terms of penalized worst-case evaluations. Notably, this generalization also includes widely used decision-making tools such as the value at risk.

Recall that $\mathcal{M}$ denotes the set of all random variables $\xi: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, where two of them are identified if they have the same law. Given $\xi \in \mathcal{M}$, we define the cumulative distribution function by $F_{\xi}(x):=\mathbb{P}(\xi \leq x)$ and set $F_{\xi}\left(x^{-}\right)=\sup _{y<x} F_{\xi}(y)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Moreover, the quantile function $q_{\xi}:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and upper quantile function $q_{\xi}^{+}:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ are defined by

$$
q_{\xi}(t):=\inf \left\{x \in \mathbb{R}: t \leq F_{\xi}(x)\right\} \quad \text { and } \quad q_{\xi}^{+}(t):=\inf \left\{x \in \mathbb{R}: t<F_{\xi}(x)\right\}
$$

Lemma B.1. For all $\xi \in \mathcal{M}$ and $t \in(0,1)$, the following statements hold:
(i) $\left[q_{\xi}(t), \infty\right)=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}: t \leq F_{\xi}(x)\right\}$.
(ii) $\left(-\infty, q_{\xi}^{+}(t)\right]=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}: t \geq F_{\xi}\left(x^{-}\right)\right\}$.
(iii) $\sup _{s<t} q_{\xi}(s)=\sup _{s<t} q_{\xi}^{+}(s)=q_{\xi}(t)$.
(iv) $\inf _{s>t} q_{\xi}(s)=\inf _{s>t} q_{\xi}^{+}(s)=q_{\xi}^{+}(t)$.
(v) The function $q_{\xi}:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is left-continuous.
(vi) The function $q_{\xi}^{+}:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is right-continuous.
(vii) The function $(s, r) \mapsto q_{\xi}(r)-q_{\xi}^{+}(s)$ is lower semicontinuous on $(0,1)^{2}$.

Proof. (i) and (ii) follow from the definitions of $q$ and $q^{+}$, using that $F_{\xi}$ is non-decreasing and right-continuous.

For $a:=\sup _{s<t} q_{\xi}(s)$, it follows from (i) that

$$
[a, \infty)=\bigcap_{s<t}\left[q_{\xi}(s), \infty\right)=\bigcap_{s<t} F_{\xi}^{-1}([s, \infty)])=F_{\xi}^{-1}([t, \infty)])=\left[q_{\xi}(t), \infty\right)
$$

where $F_{\xi}^{-1}([s, \infty))=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}: s \leq F_{\xi}(x)\right\}$. This shows $\sup _{s<t} q_{\xi}(s)=q_{\xi}(t)$. For $s<t$, it holds $q_{\xi}(s) \leq q_{\xi}^{+}(s) \leq q_{\xi}(t)$, so that $q_{\xi}(t)=\sup _{s<t} q_{\xi}(s) \leq \sup _{s<t} q_{\xi}^{+}(s) \leq q_{\xi}(t)$, which shows (iii).

Define $G(s):=F_{\xi}\left(s^{-}\right)$for all $s \in \mathbb{R}$. For $b:=\inf _{s>t} q_{\xi}^{+}(s)$, it follows from (ii) that

$$
(-\infty, b]=\bigcap_{s>t}\left(-\infty, q_{\xi}^{+}(s)\right]=\bigcap_{s>t} G^{-1}\left((-\infty, s]\right)=G^{-1}\left((-\infty, t]\right)=\left(-\infty, q_{\xi}^{+}(t)\right]
$$

where $G^{-1}([s, \infty))=\{x \in \mathbb{R}: s \leq G(x)\}$. This shows $\inf _{s>t} q_{\xi}^{+}(s)=q_{\xi}^{+}(t)$. For $s>t$, it holds $q_{\xi}^{+}(s) \geq q_{\xi}(s) \geq q_{\xi}^{+}(t)$, so that $q_{\xi}^{+}(t)=\inf _{s>t} q_{\xi}^{+}(s) \geq \inf _{s>t} q_{\xi}(s) \geq q_{\xi}^{+}(t)$, which shows (iv).

Finally, (v), (vi) and (vii) are consequences of (iii) and (iv).
Lemma B.2. For $\xi, \eta \in \mathcal{M}$, the following statements are equivalent:
(i) $q_{\xi}(u)-q_{\xi}(t) \leq q_{\eta}(u)-q_{\eta}(t)$ for all $0<t \leq u<1$.
(ii) $q_{\xi}(u)-q_{\xi}^{+}(t) \leq q_{\eta}(u)-q_{\eta}^{+}(t)$ for all $0<t<u<1$.

Proof. (ii) $\Rightarrow(i)$ : Let $0<t \leq u<1$. For $s \in(0, t)$, it holds $q_{\xi}(u)-q_{\xi}^{+}(s) \leq$ $q_{\eta}(u)-q_{\eta}^{+}(s)$. Letting $s \rightarrow t^{-}$, it follows from (iii) in Lemma B. 1 that

$$
q_{\xi}(u)-q_{\xi}(t) \leq q_{\eta}(u)-q_{\eta}(t)
$$

$(i) \Rightarrow(i i)$ : Let $0<t<u<1$. For $s \in(t, u)$, it holds $q_{\xi}(u)-q_{\xi}(s) \leq q_{\eta}(u)-q_{\eta}(s)$. Letting $s \rightarrow t^{+}$, it follows from (iv) in Lemma B. 1 that $q_{\xi}(u)-q_{\xi}^{+}(t) \leq q_{\eta}(u)-q_{\eta}^{+}(t)$.

Lemma B.3. If $q:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is non-decreasing and left-continuous, then there exists $\xi \in \mathcal{M}$ such that $q(u)=q_{\xi}(u)$ for all $u \in(0,1)$.

Proof. If $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})$ is atomless, then there exists a uniformly distributed random variable $U$ with values in $(0,1)$ defined on $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})$, see e.g. [6, Theorem 1] and [12, Proposition A.27]. Then $\xi=q(U)$ is as desired. To that end, define $F: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow[0,1]$ by

$$
F(x):=0 \vee \sup \{s \in(0,1): x \geq q(s)\}
$$

which satisfies
(1) $q(F(x)) \leq x$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$ (where we set $q(0):=q\left(0^{+}\right)$and $q(1):=q\left(1^{-}\right)$),
(2) $F(q(s)) \geq s$ for all $s \in(0,1)$.

For $x \in \mathbb{R}$, it follows from (2) that $\{q(U) \leq x\} \subset\{F(q(U)) \leq F(x)\} \subset\{U \leq F(x)\}$. Hence, for every $u \in(0,1)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
q_{\xi}(u) & =\inf \{x \in \mathbb{R}: \mathbb{P}(q(U) \leq x) \geq u\} \\
& \geq \inf \{x \in \mathbb{R}: \mathbb{P}(U \leq F(x)) \geq u\} \\
& =\inf \{x \in \mathbb{R}: F(x) \geq u\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $a:=\inf \{x \in \mathbb{R}: F(x) \geq u\}$, and $x_{n} \downarrow a$ with $F\left(x_{n}\right) \geq u$. It follows from (1) that $x_{n} \geq q(u)$, and therefore $q_{\xi}(u) \geq a \geq q(u)$ by letting $n \rightarrow \infty$.

As for the other inequality, we have that $\mathbb{P}(q(U) \leq q(u)) \geq \mathbb{P}(U \leq u)=u$. Hence, it follows from the definition of $q_{\xi}(u)$ that $q_{\xi}(u) \leq q(u)$.

Recall that for $\xi \in \mathcal{M}_{1}$, the integrated quantile function $Q_{\xi}:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is defined by

$$
Q_{\xi}(u):=\int_{u}^{1} q_{\xi}(v) \mathrm{d} v
$$

Lemma B.4. If $Q:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is concave and satisfies $Q\left(0^{+}\right) \in \mathbb{R}$ and $Q\left(1^{-}\right)=0$, then there exists $\xi \in \mathcal{M}_{1}$ such that $Q(u)=Q_{\xi}(u)$ for all $u \in(0,1)$.

Proof. Since $Q$ is concave, there exist a non-decreasing function $q:(0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and $c \in(0,1)$ such that

$$
Q(u)=Q(c)-\int_{c}^{u} q(v) \mathrm{d} v
$$

see e.g. [26, Theorem 12A]. By replacing $q$ by its left-continuous modification, we can assume that $q$ is left-continuous. Using that $Q\left(1^{-}\right)=0$, we get that

$$
Q(u)=\int_{u}^{1} q(v) \mathrm{d} v
$$

Since $q$ is left-continuous, it follows from Lemma B. 3 that $q=q_{\xi}$ for some $\xi \in \mathcal{M}$. It remains to show that $\xi \in \mathcal{M}_{1}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P}}[|\xi|] & =\int_{0}^{1}\left|q_{\xi}(v)\right| \mathrm{d} v \\
& =-\int_{0}^{F_{\xi}(0)} q_{\xi}(v) \mathrm{d} v+\int_{F_{\xi}(0)}^{1} q_{\xi}(v) \mathrm{d} v \\
& =-Q\left(0^{+}\right)+2 Q\left(F_{\xi}(0)\right)<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, $\xi$ has finite first moment, and consequently $\xi \in \mathcal{M}_{1}$.

# Appendix C. Auxiliary results for the total variation 

We consider the setting of Subsection 5.5.
Proposition C.1. The mapping $t \mapsto \mathrm{TV}_{[0, t]}(Q)$ is non-decreasing and left-continuous on $(0,1]$.

Proof. By definition, the mapping $t \mapsto \mathrm{TV}_{[0, t]}(Q)$ is non-decreasing. Given $t \in(0,1]$, we fix a partition $\pi=\left\{t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{n}\right\}$ of $[0, t]$. For every $u \in(0, t)$, we consider the partition $\pi_{u}:=(\pi \cap[0, u]) \cup\{u\} \in \Pi[0, u]$. Then since every $q \in Q$ is non-decreasing and left-continuous, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{u<t} S_{\pi_{u}}(Q) & =\sup _{u \in\left(t_{n-1}, t\right)} S_{\pi_{u}}(Q) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(t_{i}\right)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)+\sup _{u \in\left(t_{n-1}, t\right)} \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q(u)-q\left(t_{n-1}\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(t_{i}\right)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)+\sup _{q \in Q} \sup _{u \in\left(t_{n-1}, t\right)}\left(q(u)-q\left(t_{n-1}\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(t_{i}\right)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)+\sup _{q \in Q}\left(q(t)-q\left(t_{n-1}\right)\right) \\
& =S_{\pi}(Q)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\mathrm{TV}_{[0, u]}(Q)=\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, u]} S_{\pi}(Q)=\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} S_{\pi_{u}}(Q)$ for all $u<t$, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{u \uparrow t} \mathrm{TV}_{[0, u]}(Q) & =\sup _{u<t} \sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} S_{\pi_{u}}(Q)=\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} \sup _{u<t} S_{\pi_{u}}(Q) \\
& =\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} S_{\pi}(Q)=\mathrm{TV}_{[0, t]}(Q)
\end{aligned}
$$

For $[u, v] \subset[0,1]$ and $\pi \in \Pi[u, v]$, we define $\underline{S}_{\pi}(Q):=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q_{\xi}\left(t_{i}\right)-q_{\xi}^{+}\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)$.
Proposition C.2. For every $[u, v] \subset[0,1]$, it holds

$$
\mathrm{TV}_{[u, v]}(Q)=\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[u, v]} \underline{S}_{\pi}(Q)
$$

Proof. By contradiction, we assume that $\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[u, v]} S_{\pi}(Q)>\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[u, v]} \underline{S}_{\pi}(Q)$. Then, there exists $\bar{\pi}=\left\{u=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{n}=v\right\} \in \Pi[u, v]$ with

$$
S_{\bar{\pi}}(Q)>\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} \underline{S}_{\pi}(Q)
$$

Fix $\varepsilon>0$ such that $S_{\bar{\pi}}(Q)-\varepsilon>\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} \underline{S}_{\pi}(Q)$. For every $i \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\}$, the mapping $t \mapsto \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q(t)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)$ is left-continuous. Hence, there exists $u_{i} \in\left[t_{i-1}, t_{i}\right)$ such that

$$
\sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(u_{i}\right)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)>\sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(t_{i}\right)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)-\frac{\varepsilon}{n}
$$

Since $q^{+}\left(u_{i}\right) \leq q\left(t_{i}\right)$ for all $i$, we get

$$
\sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(u_{i}\right)-q^{+}\left(u_{i-1}\right)\right) \geq \sup _{q \in Q}\left(q\left(t_{i}\right)-q\left(t_{i-1}\right)\right)-\frac{\varepsilon}{n} \quad \text { for all } i \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\}
$$

where $u_{0}:=t_{0}=u$. For the partition $\pi^{\prime}:=\left\{u=u_{0}<\cdots<u_{n}<t_{n}=v\right\} \in \Pi[u, v]$, we obtain

$$
\underline{S}_{\pi^{\prime}}(Q) \geq S_{\bar{\pi}}(Q)-\varepsilon>\sup _{\pi \in \Pi[0, t]} \underline{S}_{\pi}(Q)
$$

which is a contradiction.

abstract:
In decision-making, maxitive functions are used for worst-case and best-case
evaluations. Maxitivity gives rise to a rich structure that is well-studied in
the context of the pointwise order. In this article, we investigate maxitivity
with respect to general preorders and provide a representation theorem for such
functions. The results are illustrated for different stochastic orders in the
literature, including the usual stochastic order, the increasing convex/concave
order, and the dispersive order.
